detail.content: Intro to Editing: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Introduction to Editing  FMTV-UT.1016 Studio 3 Credits Course level: Introductory    This is a hands-on course designed to introduce the student to narrative and documentary editing techniques, and to the role of the editor in shaping the final form of film and video productions. To achieve this, the class will delve into the methods, objectives, and technical aspects of post-production. It will thoroughly explore the two major editing programs (Avid and Final Cut Pro) used in today’s digital postproduction environment, and acquaint the student with every stage of the editing workflow from capture to final output.    With Final Cut Pro, students will be given a more in-depth look into the program, as well as teach and reinforce the professional standards and practices that are necessary when editing with the program. With Avid, the software will be learned in an environment that compares and contrasts it with FCP to give the user a better understanding of how it functions. At all points when new maneuvers are introduced, overarching similarities between systems will be noted. Students will learn to approach these and other non-linear programs as variations on common themes rather than as completely new and foreign tools.    In addition, the class will present examples of edited sequences from both narrative and documentary films for discussion, and have invited guests who will share their experiences in bringing films to completion.    Good editing is crucial to the success of every film & video. This course is recommended to any student, from Sophomore to Senior, who would like to gain a clearer understanding of the role of the editor as an artist, a technician, and a collaborator, along with a foundation in the software platforms in use by professional editors today. This class is also recommended to any student pursuing directing or producing who wants a better understanding of how the Post-Production work flow functions.    Enrollment is limited to 12. Not open to freshmen. Post Production: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Post Production                                          The Post Production Center (PPC) at NYU’s Kanbar  Institute of Film & Television provides all the state-of-the-art hardware,  software applications, and operational/technical support that are necessary to support  the editing needs of an artistic filmmaking community that produces almost 8000  student projects per year.                                         Approximately 150 workstations located on the 10 th   & 11 th floors of Tisch School of the Arts are loaded with Final  Cut Pro, Avid Media Composer, or Pro Tools (or combinations of all three  applications) and are available in various configurations: multi-station  computer labs; single station edit suites; ADR, Foley, Mix & Recording  studios; dubbing/duplication facilities; film & video screening rooms;  Sound FX stations, etc.). Staff  and student workers at the PPC Checkout Window on either floor are there to  give assistance and information based on the Film & Television curriculum.                                           Currently supported formats in the PPC include  HDCAM (NOT HDCAM SR), RED, DVCPRO HD, DVCAM, Panasonic  P2, Sony EX-1, and multiple file formats related to emerging technology such as  AVCHD based camcorders and Canon 7D/5D DSLRs . Students are encouraged to meet with full time PPC staff members  who are available to answer questions about these formats and workflows and to  assist students in finishing their projects. The PPC is open during the  semester seven (7) days per week, 12-14 hours per day. Students should be sure to read the PPC  signage on a weekly basis for updates on important dates such as closings,  weekly workshops, technical seminars, and other events that will add to the  creative experience here at TSOA. Intermediate Edit Workshop: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Intermediate Edit Workshop: AVID  FMTV-UT.1018 Studio 3 Credits Course Level: Intermediate     Designed to support intermediate level projects originated in: Intermediate Narrative Production Workshop, Intermediate Television Workshop, Experimental Workshop, Documentary Workshop, and Children's Television Production Workshop. Course may be repeated.    Intermediate Edit Workshop is designed to be taken the semester immediately after an intermediate film production workshop (color sync, documentary workshop, experimental workshop). Together, both courses serve to give the student a comprehensive Sync Sound Experience, from script to locked picture. In the Editing Workshop, students are expected to finish with a fine cut of their workshop exercise by the end of the semester. In addition, the class will explore the entire post-production experience; basic visual cutting of sync and non-sync material, the assembly, the rough cut, the fine cut, sound and music cutting, preparing for the mix, answer print or final print. We will also explore what an editor must know in dealing with the labs, basic organization of the editing room and the use and care of editing room tools. All stages of work are treated from the viewpoint of a professional editor.
